sentence: A representative IOP profile after SB77 treatment is shown in Fig. 1.
Additionally, the SB77 (50 µM) treated eyes showed an overall increase in tracer quantity and area along the inner wall of SC after 24 h treatment as compared to vehicle treated eyes (Fig. 2).

TM-Trabecular meshwork; SC-Schlemm’s canal and S-Sclera.Effect of SB77 on Cell Viability
Treatment with SB77 showed no significant effect on TM cell viability at all studied concentrations (Fig. 3A) (MTT assay).
In TUNEL assay, both SB77 and Y27632 (50 µM) treated cells showed no evidence of apoptosis (TUNEL-positive cells) as compared to DNase I treated cells (positive control) (Fig. 3B).

Immunofluorescence analysis revealed reduced actin bundles (F-actin), reduced vinculin-containing focal adhesions and reduced vimentin-containing intermediate filaments in drug treated cells as compared to vehicle controls (Fig. 4A).
Fig. 3. (C) Densitometry analysis of the results of 4B.

Data are expressed as mean ± SD. *p < 0.05; **p < 0.001; ***p < 0.0001, paired Student’s t-test.Immunoblot analysis revealed that HTM cells after treatment with either 50 µM SB77 or Y27632 showed significant reduction in the expression of vinculin, fibronectin, collagen 1 A (ECM protein) and vimentin as compared to vehicle controls (Fig. 4B).

Densitometry analysis showed a significant reduction in fold change in SB77-treated cells compared to Y27632 treated cells (p = 0.018 (vinculin); p = 0.000 (Fibronectin); p = 0.032 (COL1A) and p = 0.076 (vimentin)) (Fig. 4C).Effect of SB77 on Activation of RhoA and p_MLC Phosphorylation
In order to elucidate the effect of SB77 on RhoA/ROCK signal transduction, the pull-down assay for the active form of RhoA (GTP-RhoA) was carried out in HTM cell lysates after treatment.

Rho kinase inhibitor treatment significantly reduced the levels of GTP bound RhoA, thus inhibiting the activation of RhoA (p = 0.016 (vehicle control vs SB77-treated cells); p = 0.029 (vehicle control vs Y27632-treated cells)) (Fig. 5).
Fig. 4. (B) Densitometry of Western blots of active RhoA normalized to total RhoA.

Y27632 treatment also showed similar fold changes, except for the larger change in COL4A1. β-catenin mRNA levels were reduced significantly in SB77- treated cells as compared to vehicle controls (p = 0.000) but it was not found to be significant when compared with Y27632-treated cells (p = 0.088), whereas COL4A1 was significantly reduced in Y27632 treated cells as compared to vehicle-treated cells (p = 0.001) (Fig. 6).
These dose levels were chosen based on the reported IC50 value12 and also based on the toxicity profile studied in HTM cells by MTT and TUNEL assays (Fig. 4).
Cytotoxicity assays indicate that SB77 at concentrations between 0.1–100 µM was not toxic to HTM cells (more than 95% viability; Fig. 4).
The maximum response to 50 µM SB77 treatment had not reached a plateau at 24 h (Fig. 2), perhaps because the drug response is greatly influenced by the freshness of the tissue27.
The increase in OF following SB77 was associated with increased tracer distribution (Fig. 2).
Fig. 1), and reduction in actin stress fibers, cytoskeletal proteins and ECM proteins (Fig. 4).

Our study revealed that the constitutive expression of Rho GTPase (active RhoA) was significantly reduced by both Y27632 (p = 0.029) and SB77 (p = 0.016) to essentially the same extent at the studied concentrations (Fig. 5).
In the present study, a markedly greater reduction in p-MLC was observed in HTM cells treated with SB77 as compared to Y27632 treated cells (Fig. 6C).

A highly significant reduction of β-catenin expression was achieved with SB77 treatment as compared to control (p = 0.000); however, it was not found to be statistically significant when compared with Y27632 (Fig. 6; p = 0.088).

The SB77-mediated OF increase is accompanied by the inactivation of RhoA and decreased p-MLC in cultured TM cells, and thus the action of SB77 is mediated at least in part through the ROCK/MLC II pathway (Fig. 7).

Fig. 1).Cytotoxicity Assay
The effect of SB77 on cell viability of HTM was measured by MTT based assay as per the manufacturer’s protocol.
A representative IOP profile after SB77 treatment is shown in Fig. 1.
Additionally, the SB77 (50 µM) treated eyes showed an overall increase in tracer quantity and area along the inner wall of SC after 24 h treatment as compared to vehicle treated eyes (Fig. 2).

TM-Trabecular meshwork; SC-Schlemm’s canal and S-Sclera.Effect of SB77 on Cell Viability
Treatment with SB77 showed no significant effect on TM cell viability at all studied concentrations (Fig. 3A) (MTT assay).
In TUNEL assay, both SB77 and Y27632 (50 µM) treated cells showed no evidence of apoptosis (TUNEL-positive cells) as compared to DNase I treated cells (positive control) (Fig. 3B).

Immunofluorescence analysis revealed reduced actin bundles (F-actin), reduced vinculin-containing focal adhesions and reduced vimentin-containing intermediate filaments in drug treated cells as compared to vehicle controls (Fig. 4A).
Fig. 3. (C) Densitometry analysis of the results of 4B.

Data are expressed as mean ± SD. *p < 0.05; **p < 0.001; ***p < 0.0001, paired Student’s t-test.Immunoblot analysis revealed that HTM cells after treatment with either 50 µM SB77 or Y27632 showed significant reduction in the expression of vinculin, fibronectin, collagen 1 A (ECM protein) and vimentin as compared to vehicle controls (Fig. 4B).

Densitometry analysis showed a significant reduction in fold change in SB77-treated cells compared to Y27632 treated cells (p = 0.018 (vinculin); p = 0.000 (Fibronectin); p = 0.032 (COL1A) and p = 0.076 (vimentin)) (Fig. 4C).Effect of SB77 on Activation of RhoA and p_MLC Phosphorylation
In order to elucidate the effect of SB77 on RhoA/ROCK signal transduction, the pull-down assay for the active form of RhoA (GTP-RhoA) was carried out in HTM cell lysates after treatment.

Rho kinase inhibitor treatment significantly reduced the levels of GTP bound RhoA, thus inhibiting the activation of RhoA (p = 0.016 (vehicle control vs SB77-treated cells); p = 0.029 (vehicle control vs Y27632-treated cells)) (Fig. 5).
Fig. 4. (B) Densitometry of Western blots of active RhoA normalized to total RhoA.

Y27632 treatment also showed similar fold changes, except for the larger change in COL4A1. β-catenin mRNA levels were reduced significantly in SB77- treated cells as compared to vehicle controls (p = 0.000) but it was not found to be significant when compared with Y27632-treated cells (p = 0.088), whereas COL4A1 was significantly reduced in Y27632 treated cells as compared to vehicle-treated cells (p = 0.001) (Fig. 6).
These dose levels were chosen based on the reported IC50 value12 and also based on the toxicity profile studied in HTM cells by MTT and TUNEL assays (Fig. 4).
Cytotoxicity assays indicate that SB77 at concentrations between 0.1–100 µM was not toxic to HTM cells (more than 95% viability; Fig. 4).
The maximum response to 50 µM SB77 treatment had not reached a plateau at 24 h (Fig. 2), perhaps because the drug response is greatly influenced by the freshness of the tissue27.
The increase in OF following SB77 was associated with increased tracer distribution (Fig. 2).
Fig. 1), and reduction in actin stress fibers, cytoskeletal proteins and ECM proteins (Fig. 4).

Our study revealed that the constitutive expression of Rho GTPase (active RhoA) was significantly reduced by both Y27632 (p = 0.029) and SB77 (p = 0.016) to essentially the same extent at the studied concentrations (Fig. 5).
In the present study, a markedly greater reduction in p-MLC was observed in HTM cells treated with SB77 as compared to Y27632 treated cells (Fig. 6C).

A highly significant reduction of β-catenin expression was achieved with SB77 treatment as compared to control (p = 0.000); however, it was not found to be statistically significant when compared with Y27632 (Fig. 6; p = 0.088).

The SB77-mediated OF increase is accompanied by the inactivation of RhoA and decreased p-MLC in cultured TM cells, and thus the action of SB77 is mediated at least in part through the ROCK/MLC II pathway (Fig. 7).

TM-Trabecular meshwork; SC-Schlemm’s canal and S-Sclera.Effect of SB77 on Cell Viability
Treatment with SB77 showed no significant effect on TM cell viability at all studied concentrations (Fig. 3A) (MTT assay).
In TUNEL assay, both SB77 and Y27632 (50 µM) treated cells showed no evidence of apoptosis (TUNEL-positive cells) as compared to DNase I treated cells (positive control) (Fig. 3B).

Immunofluorescence analysis revealed reduced actin bundles (F-actin), reduced vinculin-containing focal adhesions and reduced vimentin-containing intermediate filaments in drug treated cells as compared to vehicle controls (Fig. 4A).
Fig. 3. (C) Densitometry analysis of the results of 4B.

Data are expressed as mean ± SD. *p < 0.05; **p < 0.001; ***p < 0.0001, paired Student’s t-test.Immunoblot analysis revealed that HTM cells after treatment with either 50 µM SB77 or Y27632 showed significant reduction in the expression of vinculin, fibronectin, collagen 1 A (ECM protein) and vimentin as compared to vehicle controls (Fig. 4B).

Densitometry analysis showed a significant reduction in fold change in SB77-treated cells compared to Y27632 treated cells (p = 0.018 (vinculin); p = 0.000 (Fibronectin); p = 0.032 (COL1A) and p = 0.076 (vimentin)) (Fig. 4C).Effect of SB77 on Activation of RhoA and p_MLC Phosphorylation
In order to elucidate the effect of SB77 on RhoA/ROCK signal transduction, the pull-down assay for the active form of RhoA (GTP-RhoA) was carried out in HTM cell lysates after treatment.

Rho kinase inhibitor treatment significantly reduced the levels of GTP bound RhoA, thus inhibiting the activation of RhoA (p = 0.016 (vehicle control vs SB77-treated cells); p = 0.029 (vehicle control vs Y27632-treated cells)) (Fig. 5).
Fig. 4. (B) Densitometry of Western blots of active RhoA normalized to total RhoA.

Y27632 treatment also showed similar fold changes, except for the larger change in COL4A1. β-catenin mRNA levels were reduced significantly in SB77- treated cells as compared to vehicle controls (p = 0.000) but it was not found to be significant when compared with Y27632-treated cells (p = 0.088), whereas COL4A1 was significantly reduced in Y27632 treated cells as compared to vehicle-treated cells (p = 0.001) (Fig. 6).
These dose levels were chosen based on the reported IC50 value12 and also based on the toxicity profile studied in HTM cells by MTT and TUNEL assays (Fig. 4).
Cytotoxicity assays indicate that SB77 at concentrations between 0.1–100 µM was not toxic to HTM cells (more than 95% viability; Fig. 4).
The maximum response to 50 µM SB77 treatment had not reached a plateau at 24 h (Fig. 2), perhaps because the drug response is greatly influenced by the freshness of the tissue27.
The increase in OF following SB77 was associated with increased tracer distribution (Fig. 2).
Fig. 1), and reduction in actin stress fibers, cytoskeletal proteins and ECM proteins (Fig. 4).

Our study revealed that the constitutive expression of Rho GTPase (active RhoA) was significantly reduced by both Y27632 (p = 0.029) and SB77 (p = 0.016) to essentially the same extent at the studied concentrations (Fig. 5).
In the present study, a markedly greater reduction in p-MLC was observed in HTM cells treated with SB77 as compared to Y27632 treated cells (Fig. 6C).

A highly significant reduction of β-catenin expression was achieved with SB77 treatment as compared to control (p = 0.000); however, it was not found to be statistically significant when compared with Y27632 (Fig. 6; p = 0.088).

The SB77-mediated OF increase is accompanied by the inactivation of RhoA and decreased p-MLC in cultured TM cells, and thus the action of SB77 is mediated at least in part through the ROCK/MLC II pathway (Fig. 7).

Fig. 1).Cytotoxicity Assay
The effect of SB77 on cell viability of HTM was measured by MTT based assay as per the manufacturer’s protocol.
A representative IOP profile after SB77 treatment is shown in Fig. 1.
Additionally, the SB77 (50 µM) treated eyes showed an overall increase in tracer quantity and area along the inner wall of SC after 24 h treatment as compared to vehicle treated eyes (Fig. 2).
